Over Adam Sandler’s ‘Pixels’ – Sunday AM Update|author=Anthony D'Alessandro|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=July 26, 2015|accessdate=July 26, 2015}}</ref> | gross = $92 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=southpaw2015.htm |title=Southpaw (2015) |website=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=June 16, 2016}}</ref> }}
'''''Southpaw''''' is a 2015 American [[Sports film|sports drama]] film directed by [[Antoine Fuqua]], written by [[Kurt Sutter]] and starring [[Jake Gyllenhaal]], [[Forest Whitaker]] and [[Rachel McAdams]]. The film follows a boxer who sets out to get his life back on track after losing his wife in an accident and his young daughter to protective services. The film was released on July 24, 2015, by [[The Weinstein Company]].
The film marked one of the last films to be scored by [[James Horner]], and one of three posthumous releases to feature his music. The film and the [[Southpaw (soundtrack)|film's soundtrack album]] are dedicated to his memory.
==Plot== Billy "The Great" Hope is an undefeated [[Professional boxing|professional boxer]] living in the suburbs of [[New York City]] with his wife Maureen and their daughter Leila. Billy's particular style of fighting often leaves him beaten and bruised. During a match in which he defends his [[light heavyweight]] world title, Billy sustains an eye injury as well as heavy blows to the face and body, leaving him coughing up blood for days. He is finally convinced by Maureen to retire before he becomes forever "punch-drunk". During the press conference at the post-match, an up-and-coming boxer Miguel "Magic" Escobar taunts Billy and tries to get Billy to fight him. At a charity event for the orphanage where he and his wife both grew up, Escobar is in attendance, and as Billy is leaving, Escobar threatens he'll take Maureen and his title away from him, and while Maureen tells Billy to let it go and go home with her, Billy's anger gets the best of him, leading to a brawl in which Maureen is accidentally shot and killed by Miguel's brother Hector, who flees.
Billy begins abusing alcohol and drugs while obsessively searching for Hector. He eventually gets a tip about Hector's whereabouts but only finds Hector's drug-addicted wife Maria, and leaves after learning Hector is a father. Billy attacks a referee out of frustration after throwing a fight and is suspended for a year, leaving him with no income and a six figure fine for ref assault. Furthermore, the networks are suing him for breach of contract, leaving him indebted and his house and belongings being repossessed. He continues to spiral out of control and nearly dies after crashing his car in a suicide attempt; he loses custody of Leila as a result, and she is put under care of [[Child Protective Services]] officer Angela Rivera. The incident drives Billy to sober up, but Leila cuts ties with him, blaming him for their predicament.
At the behest of his friends, Billy gets a job as a cleaner at a gym owned by seasoned boxer Titus "Tick" Wills, and tries to convince Tick to become his trainer. Billy's former manager, Jordan Mains, who is currently managing Miguel, arranges a fight between the two that could put Billy back in the spotlight. Tick is reluctant to train Billy, fearful he might be blinded by his vendetta against Miguel, but is motivated to do so when another of his students, Hoppy, is killed by his abusive father while attempting to defend his mother.
Seeing Billy's hard work after securing a job and keeping it, and his ability to show responsibilities of a father, a judge removes his visitation restrictions and congratulates him for his good work. Billy then takes Leila to his apartment where they have breakfast together and Leila asks if she can attend the fight. Billy, reluctant to let his daughter go to the fight because Maureen never wanted to expose their daughter to the violence in boxing, says he is unsure because Maureen used to make all the decisions for him. Leila asks if they can go visit Maureen's grave, where Leila convinces Billy to let her go to the fight to have someone by his side. Billy tells Leila that there will be people at the fight saying some harsh things, so Leila makes an agreement to go to the fight but stay only in the locker room with Angela, watching the fight via closed circuit television in the locker room.
As the match begins, Miguel has the upper hand against Billy, but, with Tick's advice, Billy has the chance to turn the tables in the final round by using the [[Boxing styles and technique#Defense|Philly shell defense]] and countering more aggressively with his left. As the round reaches its final minute, Billy pivots hard and, although fighting from a traditional stance, delivers a powerful left uppercut which knocks the champion down to the ground. Miguel manages to get up before the count is over and is saved by the bell. Billy is declared the winner by a split-decision and reunites with Leila in the locker room, where she forgives his past mistakes and they embrace.
==Cast== {{Div col}} * [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] as Billy "The Great" Hope<ref name="deadline1">{{cite web|last=Busch |first=Anita |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/03/antoine-fuqua-closes-deal-to-direct-southpaw-jake-gyllenhaal-set-to-star/ |title=Antoine Fuqua To Direct 'Southpaw' Movie Starring Jake Gyllenhaal |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2014-03-06 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> * [[Forest Whitaker]] as Titus "Tick" Wills<ref name="deadline2"/> * [[Rachel McAdams]] as Maureen Hope<ref name="deadline2">{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/05/twcs-southpaw-has-forest-whitaker-rachel-mcadams-and-lupita-nyongo-circling/ |title=Kurt Sutter's 'Southpaw' Movie Eyes Forest Whitaker, Rachel McAdams & Lupita Nyong'o |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2014-05-14 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> * [[Oona Laurence]] as Leila Hope<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwmovies/article/MATILDAs-Oona-Laurence-to-Star-in-Boxing-Drama-SOUTHPAW-20140619?PageSpeed=noscript |title=MATILDA's Oona Laurence to Star in Boxing Drama SOUTHPAW - BWWMoviesWorld |publisher=Broadwayworld.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> * [[Naomie Harris]] as Angela Rivera * [[Curtis "50 Cent" Jackson]] as Jordan Mains<ref>{{cite web|last=Smith |first=Emily |url=http://pagesix.com/2014/06/26/50-cent-joins-the-cast-of-jake-gyllenhaals-boxing-movie/ |title=50 Cent joins the cast of Jake Gyllenhaal’s boxing movie |publisher=Page Six |date=2014-06-26 |accessdate=2014-06-30}}</ref> * [[Miguel Gomez (actor)|Miguel Gomez]] as Miguel "Magic" Escobar<ref name="deadline4">{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/06/kaitlyn-dever-joins-the-greens-are-gone-miguel-gomez-cast-in-southpaw-richard-cabral-books-blood-father/ |title=Kaitlyn Dever Joins 'The Greens Are Gone'; Miguel Gomez Cast In 'Southpaw'; Richard Cabral Books 'Blood Father' |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2014-06-06 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> * Danny Henriquez as Hector Escobar * [[Rita Ora]] as Maria Escobar * [[Skylan Brooks]] as Hoppy * [[Victor Ortiz]] as Ramone<ref name="deadline3">{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/06/southpaw-adds-ex-champ-victor-ortiz-to-southpaw-cast/ |title='Southpaw' Adds Ex-Champ Victor Ortiz To Cast |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2014-06-17 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> * [[Beau Knapp]] as Jon Jon<ref name=Knapp>{{cite news|title=Beau Knapp Joins ‘Southpaw’|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/08/beau-knapp-southpaw-cullen-douglas-wrong-side-of-right/|accessdate=August 8, 2014|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=August 7, 2014}}</ref> * [[Malcolm Mays]] as Gabe * [[Clare Foley]] as Alice * [[Jim Lampley]] as himself * [[Roy Jones, Jr.]] as himself {{div col end}}
==Production== [[Eminem]] was originally supposed to play the role of Billy Hope. The film's screenwriter [[Kurt Sutter]] said the project was inspired by the rapper's personal struggles. He stated that he had taken meetings with Eminem's producing partners over the past seven years, looking for something to do together. "I know he's very selective and doesn't do a lot. But he shared so much of his personal struggle in this raw and very honest album, one that I connected with on a lot of levels. He is very interested in the boxing genre, and it seemed like an apt metaphor, because his own life has been a brawl. In a way, this is a continuation of the ''[[8 Mile (film)|8 Mile]]'' story, but we are doing a metaphorical narrative of the second chapter of his life. He'll play a world champion boxer who really hits a hard bottom, and has to fight to win back his life for his young daughter. At its core, this is a retelling of his struggles over the last five years of his life, using the boxing analogy. I love that the title refers to Marshall being a lefty, which is to boxing what a white rapper is to hip hop; dangerous, unwanted, and completely unorthodox. It's a much harder road for a [[southpaw]] than a right-handed boxer."<ref name="deadline5"/> Producers Alan and Peter Riche have given a slightly different story about Eminem's involvement however stating that they set out to make a boxing movie similar to ''[[The Champ (1931 film)|The Champ]]'' but wanted to make the story about a father-daughter relationship as opposed to ''The Champ''{{'}}s father-son story.<ref name="BI"/> Recalling Eminem's strong relationship with his daughter, they asked him and he was immediately receptive.<ref name="BI"/>
On December 13, 2010, [[DreamWorks]] acquired the script, with Eminem eyed to play the lead role,<ref name="deadline5">{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/12/dreamworks-teams-with-eminem-and-kurt-sutter-for-southpaw/ |title=DreamWorks Teams With Eminem And Kurt Sutter For 'Southpaw' |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2010-12-13 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> however the following August the studio dropped the project.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/08/eminem-antoine-fuqua-boxing-drama-southpaw-dropped-by-dreamworks-but-still-seeking-to-answer-bell/ |title=Eminem-Antoine Fuqua Boxing Drama 'Southpaw' Dropped By DreamWorks But Still Seeking To Answer Bell |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=2011-08-11 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] picked up the film that October.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jeff Sneider |url=https://variety.com/2011/film/news/mgm-closes-eminem-pic-southpaw-1118044796/ |title=MGM closes Eminem pic ‘Southpaw’ |publisher=Variety |date=2011-10-20 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> in December 2012, Eminem dropped out of the film to focus instead on his music.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/eminems-second-movie-put-on-hold-20120510 |title=Eminem delays second movie, 'Southpaw' to focus on music. |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=2012-05-10 |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> [[Antoine Fuqua]] signed on to the project in March 2014 with [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] replacing Eminem.<ref name="deadline1"/> Other casting news was announced in May 2014 with [[Forest Whitaker]], [[Lupita Nyong'o]], and [[Rachel McAdams]] officially joining the cast.<ref name="deadline2"/> In August of that year, it was announced that [[Naomie Harris]] would be replacing Nyong'o.<ref name="deadline6">{{cite web|last=Yamato |first=Jen |url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/08/naomie-harris-jake-gyllenhaal-southpaw/ |title=Naomie Harris Joins Jake Gyllenhaal In 'Southpaw' |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref>
Gyllenhaal did research for his role by doing "tons of reading on boxers, orphan boxers, the spirit of gyms all over America, children who start early, [and] the history of [[foster care]] in America"<ref name="huffington research"/> while also spending five months training as a boxer.<ref name="huffington research">{{cite web|last1=Jacobs|first1=Matthew|title=With ‘Southpaw,’ Jake Gyllenhaal’s Physical Transformations Become A One-Two Punch|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/jake-gyllenhaal-southpaw_us_55ae83dde4b07af29d567e26|website=Huffington Post|accessdate=28 March 2016}}</ref> Eminem would later praise Gyllenhaal's performance, noting that "Jake smashed it" in an interview with [[Zane Lowe]].<ref name="BI">{{cite web|last1=Guerrasio|first1=Jason|title=New movie 'Southpaw' was created for Eminem — but here's why the role ended up going to Jake Gyllenhaal|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/southpaw-eminem-jake-gyllenhaal-casting-2015-7|website=Business Insider|accessdate=28 March 2016}}</ref>
''Southpaw'' marks the first investment in an American film by Wanda Pictures, a division of [[Wang Jianlin]]'s Chinese conglomerate [[Dalian Wanda Group]].<ref name="Bloomberg"/> [[Principal photography]] began on June 16, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.studiosystemnews.com/on-the-set-for-61614-boxing-drama-southpaw-starts-american-ultra-wraps/ |title=On The Set For 6/16/14: Boxing Drama ‘Southpaw’ Starts, ‘American Ultra’ Wraps |publisher=Studiosystemnews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-21}}</ref> Filming took place in [[Pittsburgh]] and [[Indiana, Pennsylvania]], and sets in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtae.com/entertainment/extras-needed-for-new-jake-gyllenhaal-movie-to-film-in-pittsburgh-area/26097472#!bC316x|title='Southpaw' movie now filming in Downtown Pittsburgh|work=wtae|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/movies/2014/08/17/City-native-Antoine-Fuqua-filmed-his-movie-here/stories/201408170027|title=Pittsburgh native Antoine Fuqua returns to direct 'Southpaw'|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|accessdate=23 October 2014|date=2014-08-17}}</ref>
==Release== The film had its world premiere at the [[2015 Shanghai International Film Festival]] on June 15, 2015, where it was in competition,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.filmbiz.asia/news/shanghai-completes-competition-lineup|title= Shanghai completes competition lineup|author= Kevin Ma|date= June 4, 2015|accessdate= June 4, 2015|work= [[Film Business Asia]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150611191956/http://www.filmbiz.asia/news/shanghai-completes-competition-lineup|archivedate= June 11, 2015|df= }}</ref> and was released on July 24, 2015, by [[The Weinstein Company]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/southpaw-release-date-july-31-2015/|title=Southpaw Set for July 31st Release; Sacha Baron Cohen Comedy Pushed to 2016|work=Collider|accessdate=21 January 2015}}</ref>
==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Southpaw'' grossed $52.4 million in North America and $38.5 million in other territories for a total gross of $92 million, against a budget of $25 million.<ref name="BOM"/>
In its opening weekend, the film grossed $16.7 million from 2,772 theaters, finishing 5th at the box office.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-pixels-paper-towns-811139|title=Box Office: 'Pixels,' 'Paper Towns' Stall; 'Southpaw' Overperforms|author=Pamela McClintock|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=July 26, 2015|accessdate=July 26, 2015}}</ref>
===Critical response=== The [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film a rating of 60%, based on 222 reviews, with a [[Weighted arithmetic mean|rating average]] of 6/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Jake Gyllenhaal delivers an impressively committed performance, but ''Southpaw'' beats it down with a dispiriting drama that pummels viewers with genre clichés."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/southpaw_2015/|title=Southpaw|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Flixster]]|accessdate=February 14, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 57 out of 100, based on 42 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/southpaw-2015 | title=Southpaw | work=[[Metacritic]] | publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] | accessdate=July 26, 2015}}</ref> On [[CinemaScore]], audiences gave the film an average grade of "A" on an A+ to F scale.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/07/pixels-paper-towns-southpaw-trainwreck-ant-man-box-office-1201484974/|title=‘Ant-Man’ Has Bragging Rights At The B.O. Over Adam Sandler’s ‘Pixels’ – Sunday AM Update|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|date=26 July 2015|website=Deadline Hollywood}}</ref>
Soren Anderson of ''[[The Seattle Times]]'' gave the film two and a half stars out of four, saying "''Southpaw'', a boxing movie with a theme of redemption, is redeemed by the performances of its two main actors, Jake Gyllenhaal and Forest Whitaker."<ref>{{cite web|last=Andersen |first=Soren |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/movies/southpaw-hokey-boxing-film-has-fine-acting-in-its-corner/ |title=‘Southpaw’: Hokey boxing film has fine acting in its corner |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Kyle Smith of the ''[[New York Post]]'' gave the film one and a half stars out of four, saying "It brings back every stale genre convention you can think of, then hopes you won't recognize predictability pumped up with swearing and steroids and an Eminem song during the training montage."<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith |first=Kyle |url=https://nypost.com/2015/07/23/jake-gyllenhaals-southpaw-is-a-stale-cliche-filled-fight/ |title=Jake Gyllenhaal’s ‘Southpaw’ is a stale, cliche-filled fight | New York Post |publisher=Nypost.com |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Ty Burr of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' gave the film two and a half stars out of four, saying "This is a genre with especially sturdy bones, and when ''Southpaw'' connects, which is more often than you might expect, you feel it down to your toes."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/movies/2015/07/23/southpaw-old-two-punch/5bdZfJeFAj1kzPAgtdiVeO/story.html |title=In ‘Southpaw,’ it’s the old 0ne-two punch - Movies |publisher=The Boston Globe |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Ann Hornaday of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' gave the film one and a half stars out of four, saying "''Southpaw'' may be rote, predictable and mawkish, but none of those faults lie in its star. Even when he looks like an unholy mess, he transcends the movie he's in."<ref>{{cite news|last=Hornaday |first=Ann |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/jake-gyllenhaal-transforms-in-the-boxing-drama-southpaw/2015/07/22/ce0aa0fe-2fcb-11e5-8353-1215475949f4_story.html |title=Jake Gyllenhaal transforms in the boxing drama ‘Southpaw’ |publisher=The Washington Post |date= 2015-07-23|accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Steven Rea of ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "What keeps this cornball business from getting out of hand is the commitment of Gyllenhaal, whose performance is fierce and muscular, in and out of the ring."<ref>{{cite web|author=Steven Rea, Inquirer Movie Columnist and Critic |url=http://www.philly.com/philly/entertainment/movies/20150724__Southpaw___Boxing_s_life_lessons.html |title='Southpaw': Boxing's life lessons |publisher=Philly.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Michael Phillips of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' gave the film two and a half stars out of four, saying "The script may have hamburger for brains, but Fuqua slams it home with the help of actors who give their all - even when giving a little less might have made things more interesting."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/movies/ct-southpaw-movie-review-jake-gyllenhaal-20150723-column.html#navtype=barker&barkername=Barker%2006%20-%20In%20Case%20You%20Missed%20It |title='Southpaw' movie review: Jake Gyllenhaal fights through tragedy |publisher=Chicago Tribune |date= 2015-07-23|accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref>
Peter Howell of the ''[[Toronto Star]]'' gave the film two and a half stars out of four, saying "This isn't great cinema, but it's satisfying movie-making, with nothing more on its mind than telling a heart-tugging story."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/movies/2015/07/23/faces-punched-hearts-tugged-southpaw-review.html |title=Faces punched, hearts tugged: Southpaw review | Toronto Star |publisher=Thestar.com |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> [[A. O. Scott]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' said, "I wish I could say ''Southpaw'' was a knockout, or even a contender, that it went the distance or scored on points. But it's strictly an undercard bout, displaying enough heart and skill to keep the paying customers from getting too restless."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/24/movies/review-in-southpaw-jake-gyllenhaal-tries-to-box-his-way-back-from-tragedy.html?partner=rss&emc=rss&_r=0 |title=Review: In ‘Southpaw,’ Jake Gyllenhaal Tries to Box His Way Back From Tragedy |publisher=The New York Times |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31 |first=A. O. |last=Scott}}</ref> Benjamin Nugent of ''The New York Times'' has compared the film to Robert De Niro stating, "Pity Jake Gyllenhaal, who despite getting shredded for ''Southpaw'', could not outbox the shadow of Robert De Niro's ''Raging Bull'' performance."<ref>Nugent, Benjamin [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/02/t-magazine/boxing-films.html The Ring Cycle: Boxing’s Eternal Cinematic Appeal] ''New York Times''. September 3, 2015</ref> Chris Nashawaty of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the film a C+, saying "Just as director Antoine Fuqua starts to close in on something interesting and unexpected, he retreats to the safety of his corner and gives us what we've seen too many times before: a predictable flurry of melodramatic jabs."<ref>{{cite news|last=Nashawaty |first=Chris |url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/07/23/southpaw-ew-review |title='Southpaw': EW review |publisher=EW.com |date= 2015-07-22|accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Barbara VanDenburgh of ''[[The Arizona Republic]]'' gave the film three out of five stars, saying "''Southpaw'' is all about the fist. There's no delicate footwork here, no lingering grace notes. It's a film played entirely in power chords."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/movies/2015/07/23/review-southpaw-packs-little-punch/30434849/ |title=Review: ‘Southpaw’ packs too little punch |publisher=Azcentral.com |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> [[James Berardinelli]] of ''[[ReelViews]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "''Southpaw'' isn't content with presenting a gallery of clichéd characters. It takes the time to put flesh on the bones."<ref>{{cite web|author=James Berardinelli |url=http://www.reelviews.net/reelviews/southpaw |title=Southpaw | Reelviews Movie Reviews |publisher=Reelviews.net |date=2015-07-25 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref> Colin Covert of the ''[[Star Tribune]]'' gave the film one out of four stars, slamming Gyllenhaal's performance, saying "As a troubled slugger, Gyllenhaal is impressively muscle-bound, but gives no knockout performance. His work drags on like 12 rounds of fistfight fatigue."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/review-southpaw-gets-ko-d-quick-thanks-to-a-miscast-jake-gyllenhaal/318307301/ |title='Southpaw' gets KO'd quick, thanks to a miscast Jake Gyllenhaal |publisher=StarTribune.com |date=2015-07-23 |accessdate=2015-07-31}}</ref>
===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Award ! Category ! Recipient ! Result ! {{Abbr|Ref.|References}} |- | rowspan="2"|[[Black Reel Awards of 2016|Black Reel Awards]] | Best Director | [[Antoine Fuqua]] | {{nominated}} | rowspan=2| <ref>{{cite web |url=http://blackreelawards.com/black-reel-awards-16-winners-nominees/ |title=Black Reel Awards '16 |year=2016 |access-date=22 May 2018 |work=[[Black Reel Awards]]}}</ref> |- | Best Supporting Actor | [[Forest Whitaker]] | {{nominated}} |- | [[Jupiter Award (film award)|Jupiter Award]] | Best International Actor | [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] | {{nom}} | |- | [[Motion Picture Sound Editors|Golden Reel Awards]] | Sound Effects and Foley in a Feature Film | | {{nom}} | |- | [[NAACP Image Award]]s | [[NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture|Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture]] | Forest Whitaker | {{nom}} | |- | [[Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association]] | Best Youth Performance | [[Oona Laurence]] | {{nom}} | |}
==Soundtrack== {{main|Southpaw (soundtrack)}} [[Eminem]] executive-produced the soundtrack, which was released by [[Shady Records]] on July 24, 2015. He had previously released his single called "[[Phenomenal (song)|Phenomenal]]" from the soundtrack on June 2, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/eminem/85642|title=NME News Eminem to release new song on 'Southpaw' soundtrack - NME.COM|author=Rhian Daly|date=23 May 2015|work=NME.COM}}</ref>
An album of [[James Horner]]'s score was released through [[Sony Classical]] on July 24, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2015/06/02/southpaw-score-album-details/|title='Southpaw' Score Album Details - Film Music Reporter|date=June 2, 2015|work=Film Music Reporter}}</ref> This was Horner's final score (it was recorded after ''[[The 33 (film)|The 33]]'', although ''Southpaw'' was released first); he was killed in a plane crash on June 22, 2015.<ref name="CBCobit">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/pilot-dies-in-plane-registered-to-james-horner-titanic-composer-1.3123768 |title=Pilot dies in plane registered to James Horner, Titanic composer |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=June 22, 2015 |accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref>

Webb * 1973 - Short Subject: "The Comancheros" by John Harrell * 1974 - Short Subject: (tie) "The Other Nevadan" by [[Robert Laxalt]] and "Buried Money" by Eve Ball * 1975 - Short Subject: "Apaches in the History of the Southwest" by Donald Worcester * 1976 - Short Subject: "Jonathan Gilliam & The White Man's Burden" by C. The '''Symphony in C major''', [[Wagner-Werk-Verzeichnis|WWV]] 29, is the only completed [[symphony]] of [[Richard Wagner]].
== Form == The Symphony in C major is in four [[movement (music)|movements]]: * I. Sostenuto e maestoso - Allegro con brio (475 [[bar (music)|bars]]) * II. Andante ma non troppo, un poco maestoso (208 bars) * III. Allegro assai (447 bars) * IV. Allegro molto e vivace. (442 bars).
The performance time is approximately 35 minutes.
The first movement is in [[sonata form]] movement prefaced by a slow introduction. The second movement is in the key of A minor; the overall shape is A + B + B + A + [[coda (music)|coda]], a strong contrast existing between the lyrical A and the signal-like B ideas. The movement begins with a motif from the coda of the first movement. The third movement is a [[scherzo]] and [[Trio (music)#Musical form|trio]] with the traditional structure A + B + A + B + A + coda. The scherzo is characterised by a dynamic rhythm, whilst the trio (''un poco meno allegro'') features a contrasting smooth melodic line. The fourth movement is structured in the same classical sonata form as the opening movement. The idea which follows the presentation of the first theme is equivocal in [[tonality]]. Wagner accelerates the tempo (''più allegro'') half way through the coda to generate increased excitement as the music moves towards its close.
== Instrumentation == The symphony is scored for 2 [[flute]]s, 2 [[oboe]]s, 2 [[clarinet]]s in C, 2 [[bassoon]]s, [[contrabassoon]], 4 [[French horn|horns]] in C, 2 [[trumpet]]s in C, 3 [[trombone]]s, [[timpani]] and [[String section|strings]].
== Composition == According to Wagner himself, in a letter to a friend, he composed the symphony in the brief space of six weeks at the beginning of the summer of 1832. The composition shows the influence of the symphonies of Beethoven (especially nos. 3, 5 and 7) and also of the late symphonies of Mozart.<ref>Millington (2001) 309.</ref> The orchestration is in the style of [[Carl Maria von Weber|Weber]]. The work shows the composer's inexperience (he was less than 20 years old when writing it), in particular in a so-called diffuseness of the first and second movements.<ref>Overbeeke (2012) 6-7.</ref>{{dubious|reason=one persons opinion|date=December 2017}}
Wagner also started in 1834 an incomplete symphony in E major (WWV35), of which only the first movement and part of the second movement exist.<ref>Millington (2001) 310.</ref>
==Early performances== The symphony was performed in rehearsal by a student orchestra at the [[Prague Conservatory]] in November 1832, conducted by [[Bedřich Diviš Weber|Dionys Weber]], with Wagner in attendance. It received its first public performance on 15 December, at the ''Euterpe'' music society in [[Leipzig]], conducted by Wagner's early teacher, Christian Gottlieb Müller.<ref name="Deathridge 2008 180">Deathridge (2008) 180</ref> [[Clara Schumann|Clara Wieck]] described the performance in a letter to her later husband [[Robert Schumann]] dated 17 December 1832: :"Father [ [[Friedrich Wieck]] ] went to the Euterpe hall on Saturday. Listen! Herr Wagner has got ahead of you; a symphony of his was performed, which is said to be as like as two peas to [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven's]] [[Symphony No. 7 (Beethoven)|Symphony in A major]]."<ref>Cited in Newman (1976) 96.</ref>
The second public performance was at the [[Leipzig Gewandhaus]] on 10 January 1833, as part of the annual subscription concerts.<ref name="Deathridge 2008 180"/> The work received another performance at [[Würzburg]] on 27 August 1833.<ref name=grove>Grove's Dictionary of Music and Musicians, 5th ed., 1954</ref>
The score was subsequently thought to have been lost after Wagner presented it to [[Felix Mendelssohn]] in 1836 (see below), but the parts from the Prague performance were found in [[Dresden]] in 1877 in a trunk which had been left behind by Wagner when he fled the city in 1849. The work was performed again at Christmas 1882, two months before Wagner's death, for the birthday of Wagner's wife [[Cosima Wagner|Cosima]] at the [[La Fenice]] theatre [[Venice]]; it was conducted by Wagner and by [[Engelbert Humperdinck (composer)|Engelbert Humperdinck]].<ref name="Newman 1976, 96, n">Newman (1976), 96, n.</ref> Wagner made several revisions to the full score for the performance.<ref>Overbeeke (2012) 7.</ref> In a subsequent "Essay on the Revival of Youthful Works" he wrote: "If there is anything at all in this work which shows the mark of Richard Wagner, it is the fact that it is not polluted by the hypocritical stance which was to appear later and which Germans find very difficult to get the better of, and the fact that, from the outset, he remained true to himself and was unwilling to be deflected from his proper course."
==Mendelssohn and Wagner's Symphony== The same 1882 essay contains a passage in which Wagner implies that Mendelssohn had tried to deliberately suppress the Symphony.<ref>Cited in Deathridge (2008), 181.</ref> The score had in fact been given by Wagner to Mendelssohn as a gift, as is demonstrable from a letter written by Wagner on 11 April 1836; Wagner perhaps had a grievance that Mendelssohn had not subsequently conducted it.<ref>Newman (1976), 95 n.2</ref> In 1874 Wagner told Cosima that he thought Mendelssohn had destroyed the score "perhaps because he detected in it a talent which was disagreeable to him."<ref name="Newman 1976, 96, n"/> This invention was of a piece with Wagner's [[antisemitic]] attitude to Mendelssohn.<ref>Deathridge (2008), 182-7.</ref>
==Piano duet version== Fragments exist of a [[piano duet]] version of the Symphony in Wagner's hand, probably prepared in 1832 or 1833. Most of the first movement is in the [[Stefan Zweig Collection]] at the [[British Library]]; other movements are at the [[Library of Congress]] in [[Washington DC]].<ref>Searle (1999), 129-30.</ref>
==External links== *[http://imslp.org/wiki/Symphony,_WWV_29_(Wagner,_Richard) Symphony in C Major] at [[IMSLP]].

(2001), ''The Wagner Compendium'' (revised edition), London: Thames & Hudson. {{ISBN|978-0-500-28274-8}} *Newman, Ernest (1976), ''The Life of Richard Wagner, Vol.1: 1813-1848'', Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|0-521-29094-5}} *Overbeeke, Emanuel (2012), "Richard Wagner: Symphonies in C and E / Huldigungsmarsch /Kaisermarsch / Overture to ‘Rienzi’", in [http://www.chandos.net/pdf/CHSA%205097.pdf CD booklet] accompanying recording of the Symphony by [[Chandos Records]], 6-9. page.title: The Death of Captain James Cook (Zoffany)

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Zoffany Death of Captain Cook.jpg | title=The Death of Captain James Cook | artist=[[Johann Zoffany]] | year=c. 1795 | type=[[Oil painting]] | height_metric=137.2 | width_metric=182.9 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[London]] | museum=[[National Maritime Museum]] }} '''''The Death of Captain James Cook, 14 February 1779''''' is a painting by [[Johann Zoffany]]. The painting records the loss of the British explorer [[James Cook|Captain James Cook]]. The painting was completed in 1794 some years after the death of Cook in 1779. Other paintings of [[Death of Cook|the death of Cook]] were painted earlier. The [[Mahiole]] (Feathered Helmet) that was included in the painting of Cook's death by Zoffany is said to be the helmet given to Cook when he first landed in Hawaii.<ref name=ak/>
==The painting's construction== The painting is unfinished. Zoffany is thought to have based the painting on another made of Cook's death by [[John Webber]] who was the official artist on Cook's third voyage. Zoffany had been invited at one time to be an artist on one of Cook's voyages and it is thought that he may have previously painted Cook. Webber had not witnessed the death of Cook, but he would have known many of the people involved. He would have known the English sailors but he would also have seen many of the natives. When Cook and his men visited Hawaii for the second time they spent some time on the main island of Hawaii where he had been received many gifts from the Hawaiian Chief including a [[Feather cloak|feather cape]] and [[Mahiole|feathered helmet]]. Cook had been killed when he returned to Hawaii only two weeks after his second visit. His unplanned return to the island was due to a storm. Cook angered the native people by attempting to take the local chief, [[Kalaniʻōpuʻu]], as a hostage in order to get a missing boat returned. In the confusion, Cook shot a man and in the aftermath he and four marines were speared to death; the death appears unintended. Cook's replacement, Captain Clerke, was able to very quickly reestablish a relationship with the Hawaiians, and they left with little ill will.
Besides Webber's painting, Zoffany also took poses from [[Benjamin West]]'s ''[[The Death of General Wolfe]]''. The native figure is based on the classical sculpture of the [[Discobolus]] which Zoffany knew well, and included in his painting ''[[Charles Townley|Charles Townley in the Park St. Gallery]]''. Cook's pose derives from the ''[[Dying Gaul]]'', another very famous classical statue.<ref name=zoff/> The Hawaiian helmet that was included in the painting had been borrowed from a London museum and had belonged to Cook. It was the helmet given to Cook by a Hawaiian chief on his first visit to Hawaii in 1778.<ref name=ak/> The helmet is also reminiscent of a crested [[Ancient Greek]] helmet.<ref name=zoff/>
The painting's noble depictions of the natives' behaviour ignored reported details that the natives cannibalized some of Cook's body. Some of his bones were returned, but other parts of his body were kept and displayed by the islanders.<ref name="cook">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/6834744/James-Cook-and-the-Exploration-of-the-Pacific-by-Adrienne-Kaeppler-and-Robert-Fleck-review.html James Cook and the Exploration of the Pacific by Adrienne Kaeppler and Robert Fleck: review], Philip Hoare, Daily Telegraph, 20 December 2009, accessed 18 September 2010</ref>
==History== Johann Zoffany was a German-born painter who had become a successful portrait painter in London. Among his principal patrons were the royal family. [[Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz|Queen Charlotte]] had sent Zoffany to [[Florence]] where he had agreed to paint the ''[[Tribuna of the Uffizi (painting)|Tribuna of the Uffizi]]''.<ref name=royal>[http://www.royalcollection.org.uk/eGallery/object.asp?object=406983&row=0&detail=about Tribuna of the Uffizi], Royal Collection, accessed April 2010</ref> Zoffany stayed seven years and the resulting painting was not well received.
Zoffany had to leave the country and he never again got a royal commission.<ref name=royal/> He had hoped to sail with [[Captain Cook]], but as a second choice he elected to make the long journey to [[Lucknow]] where he painted the life in colonial India.<ref name=art>[http://www.illwa.org/chapter_4.htm Indian Life and Landscapes by Western Artists] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100327213724/http://www.illwa.org/chapter_4.htm |date=2010-03-27 }}, Pauline Rohatgi ''et al.'', Chapter 4, accessed April 2010.</ref> Whilst Zoffany was in India he worked with [[William Hodges]]. The construction of this painting is said to be based on a sketch by Hodges.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/johnzoffanyrahis00zoffuoft/johnzoffanyrahis00zoffuoft_djvu.txt John Zoffany, R.A. his life and works : 1735-1810], Lady Manners and J.J.Williamson, p.40, accessed 18 September 2010</ref>
Zoffany went to see a play at [[Covent Garden]] concerning the death of [[Captain Cook]] who had been killed in [[Hawaii]] on his third voyage to find the [[North-West Passage]] in 1779.<ref name=zoff>[http://www.nmm.ac.uk/collections/explore/object.cfm?ID=BHC0424 The death of Captain James Cook, 14 February 1779], National Maritime Museum, Greenwich, London, accessed 18 September 2010</ref> This is thought to have inspired him to paint the death of Cook at the hand of the Hawaiian natives. Cook had been given a [[mahiole]] (feathered helmet) and a [[feather cloak]] which was given to the [[Leverian Museum]]. Zoffany borrowed these as props for the construction of the painting which was not intended to be accurate and included poses that were taken from classic statues. This helmet remained in [[Sir Ashton Lever]]'s collection, which was originally housed in [[Leicester Square]]. The feathered helmet that had been given to Cook and included in this painting is now in a museum in Vienna.
When Cook visited Hawaii for the first time in January 1778. Cook was received by high chief [[Kalaniʻōpuʻu]]. Kalaniʻōpuʻu had with him six feather cloaks and a helmet. At the end of the meeting Cook was given the helmet and cloak that Kalaniʻōpuʻu had been wearing. On the expedition's return much of Cook's collection was exhibited in the [[Leverian Museum]].<ref name=ak>[http://www.nma.gov.au/audio/transcripts/cook/NMA_Kaeppler_20060728.html To attempt some new discoveries in that vast unknown tract], [[Adrienne Kaeppler]] Smithsonian Museum of Natural History, Washington DC. Cook’s Pacific Encounters symposium, National Museum of Australia, 28 July 2006</ref> Lever's collection was then disposed of by public lottery, was obtained by [[James Parkinson (1730–1813)|James Parkinson]], and was exhibited in the [[Blackfriars Rotunda]]. He eventually sold this collection in 7,000 separate lots, in 1806. The [[British Museum]] failed to bid on these items as Sir [[Joseph Banks]] had advised them that there was nothing of value.<ref name=ak/> Many items were purchased by [[Leopold von Fichtel|Baron Leopold von Fichtel]] for the museum in Vienna.<ref>[[s:Page:Ibis - Series 3 - Volume 3.djvu/36|The Ibis, Series 3, Volume 3]], Osbert Salvin, 1873, accessed 29 August 2010</ref>
==Provenance== Zoffany's painting was obtained in its unfinished state by Cook's widow. When she died in 1835 the painting was not mentioned specifically and it was left to [[John Leach Bennet]] who gave it to [[Greenwich Hospital (London)|Greenwich Hospital]]. The painting is now in the collection of the [[National Maritime Museum]] in [[Greenwich]], London.<ref name=zoff/>

{{Infobox artwork |image= Templi di Paestum, Pitloo 001.jpg |title=The Temples of Paestum |artist=Antonie Sminck Pitloo |year=1824 |medium=oil on canvas |height_metric= 60 |width_metric= 86 |city=Naples |museum=National Museum of Capodimonte }} '''''The Temples of Paestum''''' is an 1824 painting by [[Antonie Sminck Pitloo]]. It shows two of the temples at [[Paestum]], probably during an excavation.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/museo-di-capodimonte/oclc/868314174&referer=brief_results|title=Il Museo di Capodimonte|last=Sapio|first=Maria|last2=|last3=|first3=|date=2012|publisher=Artem|year=|isbn=9788856903034|location=Napoli|pages=|language=Italian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cir.campania.beniculturali.it/museodicapodimonte/itinerari-tematici/galleria-di-immagini/OA100002|title=Descrizione del dipinto|language=Italian}}</ref>
It was produced the same year as its artist won the landscape category in the competition organised by the Real Istituto di Belle Arti di Napoli. It was first exhibited in 1826 at the Bourbon biennial and is now in Room 58 (part of the former Royal Apartments) of the [[National Museum of Capodimonte]] in Naples.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=_UxO8xDIuuwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=9788836525775&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiFibC8vpjeAhXrct8KHSreDjcQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=Pitloo&f=false|title=Museo di Capodimonte|last=Utili|first=Mariella|last2=Spinosa|first2=Nicola|date=2002|publisher=Touring Editore|year=|isbn=9788836525775|location=Milan|pages=239|language=it}}</ref>

{{Infobox journal | title = Vestoj | cover = | editor = Anja Aronowsky Cronberg | discipline = [[Fashion]] | former_names = | abbreviation = Vestoj | publisher = | country = | frequency = Annual | history = 2009-present | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://www.vestoj.com/ | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = | OCLC = | LCCN = | CODEN = | ISSN = 2000-4036 | eISSN = | boxwidth = }} '''''Vestoj''''' (meaning "clothing" in [[Esperanto]]) is an annual [[academic journal]] about [[dress]] and [[fashion]]. The [[editor-in-chief]] and publisher is Anja Aronowsky Cronberg.
==History== ''Vestoj – the Journal of Sartorial Matters'' was established by [[editor-in-chief]] and publisher Anja Aronowsky Cronberg in 2009. It sets out to "combine theoretical knowledge about fashion with experience from the fashion industry. In the first issue a manifesto was formulated that more than anything was about bridging the gap between fashion as an academic subject of study and fashion as a business".<ref>Falk, Karin, Det Svenska Modeundret, Norstedts, Stockholm, 2011, p. 119</ref> It "stands apart from the current crop of new magazines because of its consciously intellectual stance".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ualresearchonline.arts.ac.uk/3799/ |title=Here is the secret, here is the trick |author=O'Neill, Alistair |work=UAL Research Online |accessdate=2013-06-25 |date=March 2011}}</ref> ''Vestoj'' combines scholarly texts about fashion with [[fiction]], [[nonfiction]], [[poetry]], and [[visual arts|visuals]]. Each issue is thematic and its subject matter is reflected in both editorial content and art direction. Every issue consequently has a different logo, style, format, and graphic design. In contrast to the majority of [[list of fashion magazines|fashion magazines]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=David|first1=Alison Matthews|title=''Vogue's'' New World: American Fashionability and the Politics of Style|journal=Fashion Theory|date=21 April 2015|volume=10|issue=1-2|pages=13–38|doi=10.2752/136270406778051049}}</ref> ''Vestoj'' contains no advertising and does not revolve around the fashion seasonal calendar.
==Reception== ''Vestoj'' has been called "one of the most successful attempts to provide the young academic discipline fashion studies with an equivalent to, say, the medical journal ''The Lancet''",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sidbloggen.se/2009/11/24/vestoj-allvarligt-talat-om-mode-pa-esperanto/ |title=Vestoj: Allvarligt talat. Om mode. På esperanto. Och engelska |work=Sidbloggen |author=Wirfält, Johan |date=2009-11-24 |accessdate=2013-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110053031/http://www.sidbloggen.se/2009/11/24/vestoj-allvarligt-talat-om-mode-pa-esperanto/ |archivedate=January 10, 2010 }}</ref> and journalist [[Fredrik Strage]] labelled ''Vestoj'''s first issue as one of the best new magazines in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sidbloggen.se/titlar/vestoj/ |title=Vestoj |author=Strage, Fredrik |work=Sidbloggen |accessdate=2013-06-25 |date=2010-03-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100302042016/http://www.sidbloggen.se/titlar/vestoj/ |archivedate=March 2, 2010 }}</ref> The journal was also described as a publication that "connects intellectual strength and aesthetic refinement"<ref name=interview>{{cite web |url=http://www.anothermag.com/current/view/1384/Anja_Aronowsky-Cronberg |title=An Intellectual Fashion - Anja Aronowsky-Cronberg |author=Grau, Donatien |work=AnOther |accessdate=2013-06-25 |date=2011-09-28}}</ref> and ''[[Svenska Dagbladet]]'' said that "flicking through ''Vestoj'' gives rise to the same feeling of pleasure that enjoying an old 1950s issue of ''Reader's Digest'': it's engaging, charming, personal and tongue in cheek – without ever compromising the [[intellectual]] quality".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.svd.se/kultur/mode-de-nya-tidningarna_4852911.svd |title=Mode - de nya tidningarna | Kultur |authorlink=Karin Ström |author=Ström, Karin |work=[[Svenska Dagbladet]] |accessdate=2013-06-25 |date=2010-06-11}}</ref>
In an interview on AnOthermag.com, Aronowsky Cronberg explains her approach, stating that ''Vestoj'' aims to have "an intelligent and multi-facetted approach to sartorial matters. What I find the most interesting methodology is the one that deals with both the production and consumption of a garment, as well as with the analysis of it. […] Through the study of fashion you can understand any given point in history, our desires, ideals, wants and needs. The aspect of fashion that deals with voracious consumption has spread into every way we relate to [[culture]]; today we consume ideas, knowledge and people as much as we consume goods. Fashion in that sense is nothing short of a Gesamtkunstwerk." <ref name=interview />
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.vestoj.com/}}

{{refimprove|date=January 2015}} The Kentucky '''Women Writers Conference''' had its beginnings in 1979<ref>{{cite news|title=Food writer Ruth Reichl will speak at Kentucky Women Writers Conference|url=http://www.kentucky.com/2011/12/10/1989169/food-writer-ruth-reichle-will.html|newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader|date=December 10, 2011}}</ref> as a celebration of women writers at the [[University of Kentucky]] (UK). That first year featured [[Maya Angelou]], [[Toni Cade Bambara]], [[Ruth Stone]], [[Alice Walker]], and [[Ruth Whitman]]. Since then, it has become the longest-running annual festival of women writers in the nation, showcasing the talents and issues addressed by established and emerging authors.
UK History faculty Nancy Dye had suggested using surplus funds from Undergraduate Studies to bring women writers to campus. A 16-member committee from the departments of English, Honors, Undergraduate Studies, and Special Collections, along with members of the Lexington community, produced the conference. In 1984–1985 the conference was directed by UK English faculty Jane Gentry Vance, who later served as Kentucky's Poet Laureate.
In 1985–1993, the conference was affiliated with Continuing Education for Women/University Extension and directed by Betty Gabehart. As the conference's longest-running director, Gabehart made significant contributions to its enduring legacy and stability, establishing much of the reputation it enjoys today. In 1994–1996, the conference was affiliated with the Women's Studies Program and directed by Jan Oaks, faculty in English and Gender and Women's Studies. In 1997, former Conference assistant Patti DeYoung served as director.
In 1998 the conference lost university funding when it was unable to find a sponsoring department, and its advisory board established itself as a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization. Its new home became the Carnegie Center for Literacy and Learning in downtown Lexington, and it was renamed the Kentucky Women Writers Conference. Its director during those years, 1998–2002, was Jan Isenhour, also director of the Carnegie Center, and its work was carried out by a volunteer board.
In 2002 President Lee Todd reinstated support for the conference to demonstrate the university's commitment to women's programming and community events. Since then, the Conference leadership has continued cultivating wide community support through many partnerships and the committed efforts of its board and volunteers. UK provides staff salaries, office space, and the majority of KWWC's operating expenses. Financial support from the [[Kentucky Foundation for Women]], LexArts, the Kentucky Arts Council, the [[Kentucky Humanities Council]], businesses, and individual patrons remains critical to our ability to attract writers of the highest caliber.
Directors since then have been Brenda Weber (2003) and Rebecca Gayle Howell (2004–06). Howell launched several free community events that have become signature offerings of the conference, including the Gypsy Slam, the [[Sonia Sanchez]] Series, and the Hardwick/Jones keynote reading on mentorship and collaboration. In 2007, Julie Kuzneski Wrinn became Conference director. The 38th annual conference will be held September 15-16, 2017 in Lexington, Kentucky.
